segments.text: Sign in with Apple was a feature announced by Apple in 2019, and it allows
users to authenticate into a web or mobile application using their Apple ID.
It works just like other one-click social sign-in methods like Google,
Facebook, Twitter, etc. To implement this method in your Firebase app, you'll first
need to have an Apple Developer account, which will run you about $99 per year.
Now, head over to your Apple Developer Portal. Create a new app ID or update an
existing one to use the Sign in with Apple capability. From there, you'll
create a new service ID and configure it to work with your domain. Enter the
hosting URLs from your Firebase project, then register the service ID. Now, we need
to verify ownership of this domain with Apple. Go back to the configuration for
the service ID. You'll see the option to download a file. Save that file under the
well-known directory in your public hosting folder. Then, upload this file to
Firebase Hosting by running firebase deploy from the command line. Click
verify, and you should get a green checkmark. Now, the last thing we need is
a private key. Click on keys, and then click on the key.
Then, generate a new one for Apple Sign-in. Go ahead and download this file
somewhere securely on your system. Then, open it in your editor. At this point, we
can go to the authentication tab on the Firebase console and click enable for
Apple Sign-in. Enter your team ID as well as the information from the private key.
Now, we just need to add a little bit of JavaScript to our front-end app. With
Firebase initialized, we'll make a reference to auth. Then, we'll define an
async function called sign in with Apple. It instantiates an OAuth provider for
apple.com, then awaits the auth sign in with pop-up method.
This prompts the user to log in with their Apple ID, and when they're done,
they'll be logged into the Firebase app and will have access to their user data
on the result. This has been Apple sign in with Firebase in 100 seconds, and I
realized that was super fast, so head over to Fireship.io to get a full
step-by-step breakdown of the process. Thanks for watching, make sure to like
and subscribe, and I will see you in the next one.

transcription:
Sign in with Apple was a feature announced by Apple in 2019, and it allows
users to authenticate into a web or mobile application using their Apple ID.
It works just like other one-click social sign-in methods like Google,
Facebook, Twitter, etc. To implement this method in your Firebase app, you'll first
need to have an Apple Developer account, which will run you about $99 per year.
Now, head over to your Apple Developer Portal. Create a new app ID or update an
existing one to use the Sign in with Apple capability. From there, you'll
create a new service ID and configure it to work with your domain. Enter the
hosting URLs from your Firebase project, then register the service ID. Now, we need
to verify ownership of this domain with Apple. Go back to the configuration for
the service ID. You'll see the option to download a file. Save that file under the
well-known directory in your public hosting folder. Then, upload this file to
Firebase Hosting by running firebase deploy from the command line. Click
verify, and you should get a green checkmark. Now, the last thing we need is
a private key. Click on keys, and then click on the key.
Then, generate a new one for Apple Sign-in. Go ahead and download this file
somewhere securely on your system. Then, open it in your editor. At this point, we
can go to the authentication tab on the Firebase console and click enable for
Apple Sign-in. Enter your team ID as well as the information from the private key.
Now, we just need to add a little bit of JavaScript to our front-end app. With
Firebase initialized, we'll make a reference to auth. Then, we'll define an
async function called sign in with Apple. It instantiates an OAuth provider for
apple.com, then awaits the auth sign in with pop-up method.
This prompts the user to log in with their Apple ID, and when they're done,
they'll be logged into the Firebase app and will have access to their user data
on the result. This has been Apple sign in with Firebase in 100 seconds, and I
realized that was super fast, so head over to Fireship.io to get a full
step-by-step breakdown of the process. Thanks for watching, make sure to like
and subscribe, and I will see you in the next one.
translation:
1
00:00:00,640 --> 00:00:05,440
Sign in with Apple was a feature announced by Apple in 2019, and it allows users to authenticate

2
00:00:05,440 --> 00:00:08,600
into a web or mobile application using their Apple ID.

3
00:00:08,600 --> 00:00:13,160
It works just like other one-click social sign-in methods like Google, Facebook, Twitter,

4
00:00:13,160 --> 00:00:14,160
etc.

5
00:00:14,160 --> 00:00:17,300
To implement this method in your Firebase app, you'll first need to have an Apple developer

6
00:00:17,300 --> 00:00:20,080
account, which will run you about $99 per year.

7
00:00:20,080 --> 00:00:22,620
Now, head over to your Apple Developer Portal.

8
00:00:22,620 --> 00:00:27,600
Create a new app ID or update an existing one to use the Sign in with Apple capability.

9
00:00:27,600 --> 00:00:31,940
From there, you'll create a new service ID and configure it to work with your domain.

10
00:00:31,940 --> 00:00:35,920
Enter the hosting URLs from your Firebase project, then register the service ID.

11
00:00:35,920 --> 00:00:39,660
Now, we need to verify ownership of this domain with Apple.

12
00:00:39,660 --> 00:00:41,920
Go back to the configuration for the service ID.

13
00:00:41,920 --> 00:00:44,320
You'll see the option to download a file.

14
00:00:44,320 --> 00:00:48,100
Save that file under the well-known directory in your public hosting folder.

15
00:00:48,100 --> 00:00:51,740
Then upload this file to Firebase hosting by running firebase deploy from the command

16
00:00:51,740 --> 00:00:52,740
line.

17
00:00:52,740 --> 00:00:54,760
Click verify, and you should get a green checkmark.

18
00:00:54,760 --> 00:00:57,280
Now, the last thing we need is a private key.

19
00:00:57,280 --> 00:01:00,140
Click on keys, and then generate a new one for Apple Sign In.

20
00:01:00,140 --> 00:01:03,740
Go ahead and download this file somewhere securely on your system, then open it in your

21
00:01:03,740 --> 00:01:04,740
editor.

22
00:01:04,740 --> 00:01:08,520
At this point, we can go to the authentication tab on the Firebase console and click enable

23
00:01:08,520 --> 00:01:10,000
for Apple Sign In.

24
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:13,520
Enter your team ID as well as the information from the private key.

25
00:01:13,520 --> 00:01:16,940
And now, we just need to add a little bit of JavaScript to our front-end app.

26
00:01:16,940 --> 00:01:21,060
With Firebase initialized, we'll make a reference to auth, then we'll define an async function

27
00:01:21,060 --> 00:01:22,600
called sign in with Apple.

28
00:01:22,600 --> 00:01:26,620
It instantiates an OAuth provider for apple.com, then awaits the auth sign in with popup.

29
00:01:26,620 --> 00:01:30,780
This prompts the user to log in with their Apple ID.

30
00:01:30,780 --> 00:01:34,000
And when they're done, they'll be logged in to the Firebase app, and we'll have access

31
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:35,900
to their user data on the result.

32
00:01:35,900 --> 00:01:38,920
This has been Apple Sign In with Firebase in 100 seconds.

33
00:01:38,920 --> 00:01:43,040
And I realized that was super fast, so head over to Fireship.io to get a full step-by-step

34
00:01:43,040 --> 00:01:44,640
breakdown of the process.

35
00:01:44,640 --> 00:01:48,080
Thanks for watching, make sure to like and subscribe, and I will see you in the next

36
00:01:48,080 --> 00:01:48,580
one.
